i5.las2peer.api

Class Service

  • java.lang.Object
    • i5.las2peer.api.Configurable
      • i5.las2peer.api.Service
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    NotCreatableService, NotStartingService, PackageTestService, TestService

    public abstract class Service
extends Configurable
    Base class for services to be hosted within the LAS2peer network.

    Basic Implementation Hints

    To implement a service simply derive this API class an implement the intended functionality. If parameters and results are to be transported via the LAS2peer network use types implementing the Serializable interface.

    Especially implemented helper classes like parameters and results to be transported via the network should be encapsulated into a separate jar archive so that using remote clients or other services may use this jar for their implementation.

    Please be aware, that only one instance of the service is instantiated at a LAS2peer node. There are no per user instantiations as in former LAS server implementations. To access the current user, just use the helper methods of this abstract class like getActiveAgent().

    If you want to access the current user agent, the LAS2peer node or logging from outside your service class, e.g. in helper classes or the like, you can make use of the Context class, especially of the static Context.getCurrent() method.

    Runtime Configuration

    The preferred method of providing runtime configuration of your service are simple protected fields which can be configured via property files. See Configurable.setFieldValues() and Configurable.getProperties() These methods won't be called automatically. Use these methods e.g. in the constructor of your service class.

    Deployment and Dependencies

    For dependency information please use the following (more or less OSGI compatible) Jar manifest entries: 

     Import-Library=[dependency list]
 Library-SymbolicName=[an arbitrary name}
 Library-Version=[build-version]

    For own helper and 3rd party libraries, you can use any arbitrary library name consisting of alpha-numerical characters. For Jars archives providing a LAS2peer service please use the package name of the service as library name and name for the jar archive.

    As build version please use a format of [main].[mayor].[minor]-[build] where you may leave out any of [mayor], [minor] or [build].
    The dependency list consists of a comma separated list of library dependencies of the following syntax: 

    library-name[;version=[version-info]][;resolution=optional]

    The [version-info] may state a specific version consisting at least of a main version number or define a range of compatible versions. For a range you can use square brackets indicating that the given version boundary (lower or higher) is not compatible with the import. Round or no brackets state, that the given version is included in the range.
    The statement resolution=optional defines a library, that may be used but is not mandatory.

    Additionally, you may define a Library-Name entry in the jar-manifest stating a simple human readable name for the provides service.

    (JUnit-)Testing

    For unit testing of your service within a LAS2peer setting, you can use the prepared (abstract) class LocalServiceTestCase to derive your test case from.
    This class starts a LocalNode running your service to test on each test case.

    Starting and Hosting a Service

    To start a node hosting your service, you can use the methods of the class L2pNodeLauncher, which is the main method of the LAS2peer-archive library as well.

    Further Tools

    For further tools like (testing) envelope XML file generators or the like, have a look into the classes of the i5.las2peer.tools package. There are e.g. some command line generators for XML helper files.
